FacilityName: Chevron Oronite Company LLC - Oak Point Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
LDEQ Facility ID Number - 1708

1.0  Facility

Our facility produces petroleum additives using a variety of chemicals and processing operations.  Our plant is one of the largest and most advanced producers of high-quality blended fuel and lubricating oil additives in the world. The facility serves domestic and international markets.

2.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Programs

At Chevron Oronite Company, LLC - Oak Point Plant, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of procedures, accidental release prevention programs, fire prevention programs and emergency response training and planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.    We have had one accident in the past five years that involved a covered process.

We  take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:
  Process Safety Information
  Process Hazard Analysis
  Operating Procedures
  Training
  Mechanical Integrity
  Management of Change
  Pre-Startup Review
  Compliance Audits
  Incident Investigation
  Employee Participation
  Hot Work Permit
  Contractor Safety

As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:
  Process controls, alarms, and shutdown systems
  Highly qualified operators with extensive initial and  refresher training
  Thorough operating procedures that are kept up to date
  Inspection and preventative maintenance processes
  Pressure relief and treatment systems for Ammonia, Boron Trifluoride, and 2-Methylpropene systems
  Gas detection monitors on Ammonia and 2-Methylpropene systems 
  Cameras for continuous monitoring of Boron Trifluoride handling equipment in the con

trol room
  Remote shutdown valves located at two points within the PIB Plant
  Water spray system on Ammonia, Boron Trifluoride and 2-Methylpropene vessels
  Fire hoses and monitors to "knock-down" and absorb vapors
  Well-trained Emergency Response Team on-site and available at all times

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent and mitigate accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the high safety standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

                                
3.0   Regulated Substances

In our processes, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Flammables

Methylamine                                    64,000 lbs.               Calcium Phenate Production

4.0  Accident History        

The Oak Point plant had one (1) incident on 3/6/04 that involved a covered process.  A release of 2-Methylamine (CAS 74-89-5) occurred during the unloading of a tank truck to our facility storage tank.  Methylamine gas was released to the atmosphere and methylamine liquid was released to the area drainage system where a portion of the liquid vaporized to a gas. The scrubbing system designed to trap the vapors was flooded during the incident and was unable to contain the full release.   A total

of 874 lbs. of 100% 2-Methylpropene was released.  One employee was admitted to a local hospital for observation after inhaling vapors from the release.  A second employee was also sent to the hospital for observation but was released after approximately one hour and returned to work the same day.  No other persons on-site or off-site were injured or affected and there was no property damage from this incident.  Additional details are provided in Section 6, Accident History.

5.0  Planned Changes To Improve Safety

The recent release of Methylamine at our facility has prompted us to take several measures to improve safety for all of our hazardous processes, including those that involve RMP regulated chemicals.  Improvements that are being evaluated, or have already been implemented include:
  Revision of the Methylamine tank truck unload procedure to require use of breathing air.
  Implementation of a project to simplify the Methylamine storage facility piping.
  Review and updating of the emergency response procedures to ensure they reflect current 
     practices and contact information.
  Plans for more plant drills on hazardous release response to increase awareness of, and
     reinforce knowledge of the roles and responsibilities plant personnel have during emergency
     response.  
  Individual departments, such as the Environmental Team, may increase drills to improve their
     knowledge of hazardous processes and the potential consequences involved.
  Guide Sheets that summarize essential emergency response procedures will be made available to 
     help ensure that critical emergency response tasks are carried out and not overlooked.
